[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/fn-check-client/src/get_pfns.rs] [Function: get_node_infos()] [Path Traversal] Can an attacker provide a malicious input_file path (e.g., '../../../etc/passwd' or absolute paths) to read arbitrary files from the filesystem, potentially exposing sensitive validator keys or configuration data? (High)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/fn-check-client/src/get_pfns.rs] [Function: get_node_infos()] [Symbolic Link Attack] Does File::open() follow symbolic links, allowing an attacker to create a symlink pointing to sensitive files (e.g., validator private keys, system files) and read them through the node checker? (High)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/fn-check-client/src/get_pfns.rs] [Function: get_node_infos()] [TOCTOU Race Condition] Is there a time-of-check-time-of-use (TOCTOU) vulnerability where an attacker could swap the input file between validation and reading, potentially injecting malicious node configurations? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/fn-check-client/src/get_pfns.rs] [Function: get_node_infos()] [File Descriptor Exhaustion] Can an attacker cause the File::open() call to fail by exhausting file descriptors through repeated requests, leading to denial of service in node validation? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/fn-check-client/src/get_pfns.rs] [Function: get_node_infos()] [JSON Bomb DoS] Does serde_json::from_reader() have protection against deeply nested JSON structures or extremely large JSON files that could cause stack overflow, memory exhaustion, or CPU DoS when parsing the entries vector? (High)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/fn-check-client/src/get_pfns.rs] [Function: get_node_infos()] [Memory Exhaustion] Can an attacker provide a JSON file with millions of Entry objects in the Vec<Entry>, causing unbounded memory allocation and OOM crashes on validator nodes running the node checker? [File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/fn-check-client/src/get_pfns.rs] [Function: get_node_infos()] [Deserialization Type Confusion] Could malformed JSON exploit serde deserialization to cause type confusion in the Entry struct fields (e.g., providing string where number expected), leading to unsafe memory access or panic? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/fn-check-client/src/get_pfns.rs] [Function: get_node_infos()] [Integer Overflow in JSON] Can the JSON parser handle extremely large numbers in api_port, noise_port, or metrics_port fields that exceed u16::MAX, and does it properly reject them or silently truncate causing validation bypass? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/fn-check-client/src/get_pfns.rs] [Struct: Entry] [Deserialization Validation] Does serde validation ensure that the account_address field contains only valid Aptos account addresses, or can malformed addresses cause panics or undefined behavior in downstream processing? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/fn-check-client/src/get_pfns.rs] [Function: get_node_infos()] [JSON Schema Bypass] Can an attacker include extra unexpected fields in the JSON that get silently ignored by serde, potentially bypassing validation logic that should reject malformed entries? [File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/fn-check-client/src/get_pfns.rs] [Function: get_node_infos()] [Allowlist Bypass] Can an attacker bypass the account_address_allowlist check by providing account addresses in different formats (e.g., with/without 0x prefix, different case, different length padding) that pass allowlist check but resolve to different actual addresses? [File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/fn-check-client/src/get_pfns.rs] [Function: get_node_infos()] [Empty Allowlist Interpretation] Does an empty account_address_allowlist (is_empty() returns true) correctly mean 'allow all addresses', and could this create an unintended open registration system allowing any attacker node to register? [File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/fn-check-client/src/get_pfns.rs] [Function: get_node_infos()] [Allowlist String Comparison] Does the allowlist comparison use account_address.to_string() which might have different formatting than the allowlist entries, creating bypass opportunities through format inconsistencies? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/fn-check-client/src/get_pfns.rs] [Function: get_node_infos()] [Case Sensitivity Attack] Is the allowlist comparison case-sensitive, and can attackers bypass it by using different case variations (0xABC vs 0xabc) if AccountAddress::to_string() normalizes differently than allowlist entries? [File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/fn-check-client/src/get_pfns.rs] [Function: get_node_infos()] [Leading Zeros Bypass] Can account addresses with different numbers of leading zeros (0x001 vs 0x1) bypass the allowlist check while representing the same address? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/fn-check-client/src/get_pfns.rs] [Impl: TryInto<NodeInfo>] [SSRF via URL] Does Url::parse() allow file:// or internal network URLs (localhost, 127.0.0.1, 169.254.x.x) that could enable SSRF attacks when the node checker attempts to connect to these malicious URLs? [File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/fn-check-client/src/get_pfns.rs] [Impl: TryInto<NodeInfo>] [URL Parser DoS] Can extremely long URLs (>1MB) or URLs with thousands of query parameters cause Url::parse() to consume excessive CPU or memory, leading to DoS during node validation? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/fn-check-client/src/get_pfns.rs] [Impl: TryInto<NodeInfo>] [Protocol Validation Missing] Does the code validate that only http:// or https:// schemes are allowed in node_url, or can attackers specify ws://, ftp://, or other protocols causing unexpected behavior in node checking logic? [File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/fn-check-client/src/get_pfns.rs] [Impl: TryInto<NodeInfo>] [URL Unicode Exploit] Can URLs containing Unicode characters, homograph attacks, or non-ASCII domains bypass validation and cause issues when the node checker connects to these endpoints? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/fn-check-client/src/get_pfns.rs] [Impl: TryInto<NodeInfo>] [URL Authority Bypass] Can URLs with embedded credentials (http://user:pass@host) or unusual authority sections cause security issues or information disclosure in error messages? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/fn-check-client/src/get_pfns.rs] [Impl: TryInto<NodeInfo>] [Weak Public Key Acceptance] Does the code validate that the parsed x25519 public key is cryptographically valid (not low-order points, not identity element), or can attackers register nodes with weak/invalid keys that compromise security?
